title: Accumulation of area under a radical function

content.question:
Let f be the function given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>=</mo> <msqrt> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>−</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </msqrt> </mrow> <annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaamOzaiaacI cacaWG4bGaaiykaiabg2da9maakaaabaGaamiEaiabgkHiTiaaioda aSqabaaaaa@3CFF@</annotation> </semantics> </math>.

(a) On the axes provided below, sketch the graph of f and shade the region R enclosed by the graph of f, the x-axis, and the vertical line x = 6.

frqParts.text:
Let f be the function given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>=</mo> <msqrt> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>−</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </msqrt> </mrow> <annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaamOzaiaacI cacaWG4bGaaiykaiabg2da9maakaaabaGaamiEaiabgkHiTiaaioda aSqabaaaaa@3CFF@</annotation> </semantics> </math>.

(a) On the axes provided below, sketch the graph of f and shade the region R enclosed by the graph of f, the x-axis, and the vertical line x = 6.
(b) Find the area of the region R described in part (a).

(c) Rather than using the line x = 6 as in part (a), consider the line x = w, where w can be any number greater than 3. Let A(w) be the area of the region enclosed by the graph of f, the x-axis, and the vertical line x = w. Write an integral expression for A(w).
(d) Let A(w) be as described in part (c). Find the rate of change of A with respect to w when w = 6.

topic.text: 6.4: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus and Accumulation Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
